newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: World Bank optimistic on Guatemalan economy.
newsitem.headline: World Bank optimistic on Guatemalan economy.

text.p: The World Bank expects Guatemala's economy to grow four to 4.5 percent this year and to maintain an inflation rate of around 10 percent, a bank representative said on Thursday.

"According to the first quarter results there is no reason to believe that the government will not be able to reach its macroeconomic goals for 1997," said Jose Roberto Lopez, the World Bank resident representative in Guatemala.
The Guatemalan government has previously set 1997 targets of 4.0 to 4.5 percent growth and 10 percent inflation.
Lopez said positive first quarter indicators include an increase in international reserves of $100 million as well as strong growth in exports and imports during the first quarter.
Guatemala's central bank reported this week that first quarter 1997 exports rose 45 percent over the same 1996 period.
"We also understand that the government is making efforts to reach its fiscal goals," Lopez said.
According to Lopez, sustained growth would depend on increased consumer credit and a reduction in Guatemala's high interest rates.
He warned that the government should correct volatile interest rates, the too-wide 5-10 percent spread between active and passive interest rates, and slow growth in consumer credit.

"Interest rates continue to be a worrying element because for the private sector to be able to invest it needs clear and stable rules and this means a lowering trend in interest rates should be maintained," Lopez said.
Average bank interest rates for consumer loans varied between 20 to 30 percent in 1996.
Lopez announced on Thursday a $33 million World Bank loan for Guatemala's Education Ministry.

The World Bank loaned Guatemala $60 million in 1996. The institution has promised to make loans of $100 million each year from 1997-1999 to help the country implement peace accords signed in December, which ended 36 years of civil war.
The new loan funds will go for primary schools in rural and poor areas, improving the quality of teaching in rural schools and institutional support for the ministry, Lopez said.
